name: nytimes
text:
76% of U.S. voters will be eligible to receive a ballot in the mail — the most in history. 

Mail voting is more accessible this fall than ever before in part because concerns about virus transmission at polling places have forced states to make changes.
https://t.co/K3i5SXqPy3

name: nytimes
text:
Several states that made changes for the primaries are keeping them in place for the general election, while others are making separate adjustments for the fall.

More changes could come through legislation and other means. https://t.co/PSHK2tfHsd https://t.co/Rb8Du5GIkS

name: nytimes
text:
During the primaries, states that made it easier to vote by mail saw higher turnout than ones that made fewer changes.

6 states required voters to have an excuse other than the virus to vote absentee. There, voter turnout stayed roughly the same as 2016. https://t.co/PSHK2tfHsd

name: nytimes
text: Some states identified as solid or likely Democratic have implemented some of the most expansive mail voting programs. Some states identified as solid or likely Republican have continued to restrict access to mail voting. https://t.co/PSHK2tfHsd https://t.co/XCvzNQcl2H

name: nytimes
text:
If recent election trends hold and turnout increases, as experts predict, roughly 80 million mail ballots will flood elections offices this fall, more than double the number that were returned in 2016.

See more on the states’ election rules. https://t.co/PSHK2tfHsd
